Context: As a kid, I loved lounging in the swimming pool during the dog days of summer.
Meaning: Hot, sultry summer weather; also, a period of stagnation. The term alludes to the period between early July and early September, when Sirius, the so-called Dog Star, rises and sets with the sun. The ancient Romans called this phenomenon dies caniculares, which was translated as "dog days" in the first half of the 1500s.
Explanation: Clima caluroso y bochornoso de verano; también, un período de estancamiento. El término alude al período comprendido entre principios de julio y principios de septiembre, cuando Sirio, la llamada Estrella Perro, sale y se pone con el sol. Los antiguos romanos llamaron a este fenómeno dies caniculares, que en la primera mitad del siglo XVI se tradujo como "días de perros".

Context: Enid screamed blue murder when she noticed the snake in the rocks next to her.
Meaning: shout loudly in pain, fear, or anger. The second term appears to have originated as a play on the French expletive morbleu (mort bleu translates as “blue murder”). The Hotten Dictionary of Slang (1859) defined it as a desperate or alarming cry. The term was used by Dion Boucicault about 1874: “They were standing by and trying to screech blue murder” (quoted in M. R. Booth, English Plays of the Nineteenth Century; cited by OED). It is heard less often, at least in America, than the more graphic bloody murder, dating from the first half of the 1900s. For example, “The one-year-old who has yelled bloody murder during his physical . . .” (B. Spock, Problems of Parents, 1962).
Explanation: gritar fuerte de dolor, miedo o ira. El segundo término parece haberse originado como un juego de palabras con el insulto francés morbleu (mort bleu se traduce como "asesinato azul"). El Diccionario Hotten de Argot (1859) lo definió como un grito desesperado o alarmante. El término fue utilizado por Dion Boucicault alrededor de 1874: “Estaban esperando e intentando chillar un asesinato azul” (citado en M. R. Booth, English Plays of the Nineteenth Century; citado por OED). Se escucha con menos frecuencia, al menos en Estados Unidos, que el asesinato sangriento más gráfico, que data de la primera mitad del siglo XX. Por ejemplo, “El niño de un año que gritó un asesinato sangriento durante su examen físico. . .” (B. Spock, Problemas de los padres, 1962).

Context: Enid screamed blue murder when she noticed the snake in the rocks next to her.

Context: The company started as a lame duck that was saved by an innovative entrepreneur who decided to take some risks and go in a new direction.
Meaning: An elected officeholder whose term of office has not yet expired but who has failed to be re-elected and therefore cannot garner much political support for initiatives. For example, You can't expect a lame duck President to get much accomplished; he's only got a month left in office . This expression originated in the 1700s and then meant a stockbroker who did not meet his debts. It was transferred to officeholders in the 1860s. The Lame Duck Amendment, 20th to the U.S. Constitution, calls for Congress and each new President to take office in January instead of March (as before), thereby eliminating the lame-duck session of Congress.
Explanation: Un funcionario electo cuyo mandato aún no ha expirado pero que no ha podido ser reelegido y, por lo tanto, no puede obtener mucho apoyo político para sus iniciativas. Por ejemplo, no se puede esperar que un presidente saliente consiga grandes logros; sólo le queda un mes en el cargo. Esta expresión se originó en el siglo XVIII y luego significaba un corredor de bolsa que no cumplía con sus deudas. Fue transferido a los funcionarios en la década de 1860. La Enmienda saliente, número 20 de la Constitución de los Estados Unidos, exige que el Congreso y cada nuevo presidente asuman sus cargos en enero en lugar de marzo (como antes), eliminando así la sesión saliente del Congreso.
